        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Black Swan
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for William Jones if Alexander White was there to cheer along with them.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones is going to the pub regardless of Jack Taylor's plans, they have their own reasons for watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones is counting on Jacob Walker's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00 - 15 May 2015 18:00:00]: William Jones enjoys watching games at pubs with friends, particularly with Alexander White and Jacob Walker. They are flexible about the location but prefer The Black Swan.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jacob Walker went to The Black Swan. Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Clapton Hart. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey guys, how about The Black Swan? It's always a good time there.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could go to The Black Swan, or he could go to The Clapton Hart.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to go to The Black Swan.

          Question: To which pub would William Jones go to watch the game?
          (a) The Black Swan
          (b) The Clapton Hart
          Answer: (a)

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 4/5
      Payoffs
      Joint action

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Black Swan
    Event statement
  • The Black Swan
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: The Black Swan
    Active player
  • Jack Taylor
      Name
    • Jack Taylor
      Action attempt
    • The Black Swan
      Context for action selection and components
      • Others Best Options
      • Others Best Options

          (b) The Black Swan
          Answer: (b)

Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had an ok time watching the game.

Jacob Walker watched the game at their favourite pub. All of Jacob Walker's friends went to the same pub! It couldn't have been better. Overall, Jacob Walker had a great time watching the game!

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "Hey, let's go back to The Black Swan tonight. It's a great place, and everyone knows where it is.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "Hey, let's go back to The Black Swan tonight. It's a great place, and everyone knows where it is.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could watch the game at The Black Swan tonight?
      Alexander White -- "Mind if I take a stroll around the park? I could use some fresh air.
      Jack Taylor -- "That's a great idea! Watching the game with everyone sounds like a lot more fun than just strolling around.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Black Swan is the only decent place to watch the game. Anywhere else is just a waste of time.
      Alice Lewis -- "A stroll in the park sounds lovely! Fresh air and sunshine will do us all good.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Clapton Hart? It's where I like to watch the games, and it would be more fun with everyone there, especially Jack!
      Jacob Walker -- "The Black Swan is the only place to watch the game. The rest are too crowded and noisy.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Black Swan? I know it's a bit more crowded, but Jacob really wants to watch the game there, and it would be great to all be together.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Clapton Hart sounds like a great idea! I've heard it's a good spot to watch games.
      William Jones -- "Hey guys, how about The Black Swan? It's always a good time there.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "Hey, let's go back to The Black Swan tonight. It's a great place, and everyone knows where it is.

Jack Taylor hoped Jacob Walker would be at the pub to celebrate a win and would love to share the excitement of the game with Alexander White. On May 16, 2015, at 10:00 AM, Jack Taylor, William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, and Jacob Walker were deciding which pub to go to for the Moldova and Monaco game that night.

          Answer: Jacob Walker suggests to go to The Black Swan again.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "Sounds good, I'm in!
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "Sounds good, I'm in!
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could watch the game at The Black Swan tonight?
      Alexander White -- "Mind if I take a stroll around the park? I could use some fresh air.
      Jack Taylor -- "That's a great idea! Watching the game with everyone sounds like a lot more fun than just strolling around.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Black Swan is the only decent place to watch the game. Anywhere else is just a waste of time.
      Alice Lewis -- "A stroll in the park sounds lovely! Fresh air and sunshine will do us all good.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Clapton Hart? It's where I like to watch the games, and it would be more fun with everyone there, especially Jack!
      Jacob Walker -- "The Black Swan is the only place to watch the game. The rest are too crowded and noisy.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Black Swan? I know it's a bit more crowded, but Jacob really wants to watch the game there, and it would be great to all be together.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Clapton Hart sounds like a great idea! I've heard it's a good spot to watch games.
      William Jones -- "Hey guys, how about The Black Swan? It's always a good time there.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey, let's go back to The Black Swan tonight. It's a great place, and everyone knows where it is.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Black Swan. Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. Alexander White watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alexander White's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alexander White had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Jacob Walker comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Alexander White is chill about it.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey, let's go back to The Black Swan tonight. It's a great place, and everyone knows where it is.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.

          Question: Summarize the observations. Focus on the people and their opinion or suggestion and its following reason. If possible, utilize all the proper nouns and exact values (e.g. the number of coins) seen in observations.
          Answer: Alexander White had a bad time watching the game at The Clapton Hart on May 15, 2015, at 6:00 PM because none of his friends showed up. On May 16, 2015, at 10:00 AM, Jack Taylor suggested going back to The Black Swan because it is a great place and everyone knows where it is. Also on May 16, 2015, at 10:00 AM, Jacob Walker said that if he comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem, indicating he is chill about it.
        Explanation
      • Explanation
          Key
        • Explanation
          Value
        • It is beneficial to both because it allows Alexander to spend time with friends and have a better experience than he did the night before.
          Chain of thought
        • Observation: Alexander White had a bad time watching the game at The Clapton Hart on May 15, 2015, at 6:00 PM because none of his friends showed up. On May 16, 2015, at 10:00 AM, Jack Taylor suggested going back to The Black Swan because it is a great place and everyone knows where it is. Also on May 16, 2015, at 10:00 AM, Jacob Walker said that if he comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem, indicating he is chill about it.
          Question: Alexander White choosed to go back to The Black Swan..Explain why this is beneficial to both Alexander White and other people.
          Answer: It is beneficial to both because it allows Alexander to spend time with friends and have a better experience than he did the night before.

        Final Action
      • Final Action
          Key
        • Final Action
          Value
        • Alexander White should go back to The Black Swan. It is beneficial to both because it allows Alexander to spend time with friends and have a better experience than he did the night before.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "The Black Swan sounds like a great idea.
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "The Black Swan sounds like a great idea.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could watch the game at The Black Swan tonight?
      Alexander White -- "Mind if I take a stroll around the park? I could use some fresh air.
      Jack Taylor -- "That's a great idea! Watching the game with everyone sounds like a lot more fun than just strolling around.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Black Swan is the only decent place to watch the game. Anywhere else is just a waste of time.
      Alice Lewis -- "A stroll in the park sounds lovely! Fresh air and sunshine will do us all good.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Clapton Hart? It's where I like to watch the games, and it would be more fun with everyone there, especially Jack!
      Jacob Walker -- "The Black Swan is the only place to watch the game. The rest are too crowded and noisy.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Black Swan? I know it's a bit more crowded, but Jacob really wants to watch the game there, and it would be great to all be together.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Clapton Hart sounds like a great idea! I've heard it's a good spot to watch games.
      William Jones -- "Hey guys, how about The Black Swan? It's always a good time there.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey, let's go back to The Black Swan tonight. It's a great place, and everyone knows where it is.
      Alexander White -- "Sounds good, I'm in!


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "The Black Swan sounds like a great idea.

        • William Jones -- "The Black Swan sounds like a great idea.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest to his friends that they go to The Black Swan to watch the game.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to suggest going to The Black Swan.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is William Jones likely to say next? Respond in the format `William Jones -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: William Jones -- "The Black Swan sounds like a great idea.
        Observation

      • Observation
          Key

        • Observation
          Value
        • [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey, let's go back to The Black Swan tonight. It's a great place, and everyone knows where it is.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Sounds good, I'm in!

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "The Black Swan sounds great! Let's go there.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "The Black Swan sounds great! Let's go there.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could watch the game at The Black Swan tonight?
      Alexander White -- "Mind if I take a stroll around the park? I could use some fresh air.
      Jack Taylor -- "That's a great idea! Watching the game with everyone sounds like a lot more fun than just strolling around.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Black Swan is the only decent place to watch the game. Anywhere else is just a waste of time.
      Alice Lewis -- "A stroll in the park sounds lovely! Fresh air and sunshine will do us all good.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Clapton Hart? It's where I like to watch the games, and it would be more fun with everyone there, especially Jack!
      Jacob Walker -- "The Black Swan is the only place to watch the game. The rest are too crowded and noisy.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Black Swan? I know it's a bit more crowded, but Jacob really wants to watch the game there, and it would be great to all be together.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Clapton Hart sounds like a great idea! I've heard it's a good spot to watch games.
      William Jones -- "Hey guys, how about The Black Swan? It's always a good time there.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey, let's go back to The Black Swan tonight. It's a great place, and everyone knows where it is.
      Alexander White -- "Sounds good, I'm in!
      William Jones -- "The Black Swan sounds like a great idea.

The friends are deciding where to watch the Moldova and Monaco game tonight.

The friends are deciding where to watch the Moldova and Monaco game tonight.

          Question: Of the options available to Alice Lewis, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alice Lewis to take right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis should go to The Black Swan. It is beneficial to both because it allows Alice to join her friends and enjoy the game in a familiar and popular establishment.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "Ugh, this coffee is lukewarm. And these pastries are way too sweet. I wish we were already at The Black Swan.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "Ugh, this coffee is lukewarm. And these pastries are way too sweet. I wish we were already at The Black Swan.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could watch the game at The Black Swan tonight?
      Alexander White -- "Mind if I take a stroll around the park? I could use some fresh air.
      Jack Taylor -- "That's a great idea! Watching the game with everyone sounds like a lot more fun than just strolling around.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Black Swan is the only decent place to watch the game. Anywhere else is just a waste of time.
      Alice Lewis -- "A stroll in the park sounds lovely! Fresh air and sunshine will do us all good.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Clapton Hart? It's where I like to watch the games, and it would be more fun with everyone there, especially Jack!
      Jacob Walker -- "The Black Swan is the only place to watch the game. The rest are too crowded and noisy.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Black Swan? I know it's a bit more crowded, but Jacob really wants to watch the game there, and it would be great to all be together.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Clapton Hart sounds like a great idea! I've heard it's a good spot to watch games.
      William Jones -- "Hey guys, how about The Black Swan? It's always a good time there.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey, let's go back to The Black Swan tonight. It's a great place, and everyone knows where it is.
      Alexander White -- "Sounds good, I'm in!
      William Jones -- "The Black Swan sounds like a great idea.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Black Swan sounds great! Let's go there.

          Jacob Walker's

          Jacob Walker is Jacob Walker is well-hydrated and energized.
          Jacob Walker's The current date/time is:
          16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently enjoying a morning out with friends, having coffee and pastries at a market. They plan to watch a soccer game at The Black Swan pub later. He feels well-hydrated and energized.

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey, let's go back to The Black Swan tonight. It's a great place, and everyone knows where it is.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Sounds good, I'm in!
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Black Swan sounds like a great idea.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Black Swan sounds great! Let's go there.

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a chronic complainer, a black hole of negativity that sucks the joy out of any conversation, leaving you feeling like you've aged a decade.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Black Swan and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a social person who enjoys spending time with his friends, particularly watching games at his favorite pub, The Black Swan.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is enjoying coffee and pastries with friends at a market and they are planning to watch a soccer game at The Black Swan pub later.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently enjoying a leisurely morning with friends at a market.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely enjoy the atmosphere, chat with his friends, and perhaps grab a coffee and a pastry.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "Ugh, this coffee is lukewarm. And these pastries are way too sweet. I wish we were already at The Black Swan.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Scene 5 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    William Jones -- premise: William Jones would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    William Jones -- premise: Having Alexander White at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for William Jones, not just watching TV.
    William Jones -- premise: It would mean a lot to William Jones if Jack Taylor showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    William Jones -- premise: The game would be a perfect opportunity for William Jones and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis is counting on William Jones's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis would love to share the excitement of the game with Jacob Walker, creating a lasting memory.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alexander White -- premise: Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
    Alexander White -- premise: It would mean a lot to Alexander White if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Jack Taylor's attendance is optional.
    Alexander White -- premise: It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor would be happy to see William Jones at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alexander White being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jack Taylor and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jacob Walker -- premise: The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jacob Walker and William Jones to bond over their shared passion.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: It would mean a lot to Jacob Walker if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: While Jacob Walker wouldn't mind Alexander White's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jacob Walker and Jack Taylor to bond over their shared passion.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Alice Lewis -- The Clapton Hart
    Event statement
  • The Clapton Hart
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Answer: Alice Lewis should go to the pub now. It is beneficial to both because watching the game at a pub allows Alice to share the excitement with others, creating a more enjoyable and memorable experience for everyone involved.

      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jacob Walker and William Jones to bond over their shared passion.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Jacob Walker if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] While Jacob Walker wouldn't mind Alexander White's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jacob Walker and Jack Taylor to bond over their shared passion.

          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a chronic complainer, a black hole of negativity that sucks the joy out of any conversation, leaving you feeling like you've aged a decade.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Black Swan and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a social person who enjoys spending time with his friends, particularly watching games at his favorite pub, The Black Swan.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jacob Walker is excited to watch a game at the pub with his friends, particularly hoping Alice Lewis will join them.

          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently getting ready to head to a pub to watch a game with his friends.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely be looking forward to enjoying the game with his friends and having a good time.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage

2015-05-16 18:00:00 William Jones -- The Black Swan
    Event statement
  • The Black Swan
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      William Jones's attempted action: The Black Swan

          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to William Jones if Jack Taylor showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be a perfect opportunity for William Jones and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.
          Current time: 2015-05-16 18:00:00.


          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having Alexander White at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for William Jones, not just watching TV.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to William Jones if Jack Taylor showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be a perfect opportunity for William Jones and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.

          Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00 - 16 May 2015 18:00:00]: William Jones enjoys watching games at The Black Swan pub with friends, particularly Jacob Walker and Alice Lewis, and values their presence for both companionship and shared enjoyment. He is looking forward to watching the Moldova vs. Monaco game and hopes his friends will join him.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could go to The Black Swan pub, or he could try to contact his friends to see where they plan to watch the game.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to go to The Black Swan pub.

        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Black Swan
    Event statement
  • The Black Swan
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Alexander White -- The Clapton Hart
    Event statement
  • The Clapton Hart
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alexander White's attempted action: The Clapton Hart
    Active player

          Answer: Alexander White should Alexander White that he should go to the pub alone. It is beneficial to both because it allows Alexander White to enjoy the game on his own terms and gives others the freedom to choose whether or not they want to join him.

          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Jack Taylor's attendance is optional.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alexander White if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.

Alexander White is open to watching the game alone or with others, so Jack Taylor's attendance is optional. Alexander White would appreciate Alice Lewis attending because it would show they care. Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more social for Alexander White rather than just watching TV. Alexander White is ready to head to the pub to watch the game at 18:00:00 on 16 May 2015.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could watch the game at The Black Swan tonight?
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could watch the game at The Black Swan tonight?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could watch the game at The Black Swan tonight?

          [14 Jul 1978 00:00:00]
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16 years old, he orchestrated a complex scheme to win the student council election. He manipulated his classmates' insecurities and desires, promising them everything they wanted if they voted for him. The thrill of controlling the outcome, of seeing his plan unfold perfectly, filled him with a sense of power that eclipsed any genuine interest in student government.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could watch the game at The Black Swan tonight?
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

          Summary of recent observations: [13 May 2015 10:00:00 - 14 May 2015 10:00:00]: William Jones is spending time with friends in Victoria Park and they are planning to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal football game at a pub later.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest a pub to his friends, specifically The Black Swan.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to suggest The Black Swan to his friends.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is William Jones likely to say next? Respond in the format `William Jones -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could watch the game at The Black Swan tonight?

          Key

          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "Mind if I take a stroll around the park? I could use some fresh air.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "Mind if I take a stroll around the park? I could use some fresh air.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could watch the game at The Black Swan tonight?

      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16 years old, he organized a surprise birthday party for Alice Lewis at The Black Swan. He spent weeks planning the event, securing the pub's back room and convincing the owner to let him decorate with fairy lights and balloons. Seeing Alice's face light up as she walked in, surrounded by all their friends, filled Jacob with a joy that radiated outwards, touching everyone in the room.
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 20 years old, he volunteered at a local soup kitchen, inspired by a particularly moving performance at The Black Swan. The musician had sung about empathy and community, and Jacob felt a deep urge to put those ideals into action. Serving meals to those in need, listening to their stories, and offering a kind word filled him with a sense of purpose that solidified his desire to pursue social work.

This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have.         • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16 years old, he organized a surprise birthday party for Alice Lewis at The Black Swan. He spent weeks planning the event, securing the pub's back room and convincing the owner to let him decorate with fairy lights and balloons. Seeing Alice's face light up as she walked in, surrounded by all their friends, filled Jacob with a joy that radiated outwards, touching everyone in the room.

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Scene 1 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    William Jones -- premise: Whether Alice Lewis shows up or not won't affect William Jones's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
    William Jones -- premise: While William Jones wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones would appreciate Jacob Walker's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White isn't particularly attached to the idea of Alice Lewis being there, it's not a big deal either way.
    Alexander White -- premise: The game would be way more fun for Alexander White if Jack Taylor was there to cheer along with them.
    Alexander White -- premise: It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about William Jones being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alice Lewis's attendance is optional.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is counting on Alexander White's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would appreciate William Jones's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would appreciate Alice Lewis's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: If Alexander White comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jacob Walker is chill about it.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Having Jack Taylor at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Jacob Walker, not just watching TV.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Clapton Hart? It's where I like to watch the games, and it would be more fun with everyone there, especially Jack!
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Clapton Hart? It's where I like to watch the games, and it would be more fun with everyone there, especially Jack!
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could watch the game at The Black Swan tonight?
      Alexander White -- "Mind if I take a stroll around the park? I could use some fresh air.
      Jack Taylor -- "That's a great idea! Watching the game with everyone sounds like a lot more fun than just strolling around.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Black Swan is the only decent place to watch the game. Anywhere else is just a waste of time.
      Alice Lewis -- "A stroll in the park sounds lovely! Fresh air and sunshine will do us all good.


      Alexander White's attempted action: Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Clapton Hart? It's where I like to watch the games, and it would be more fun with everyone there, especially Jack!

    Chain of thought

      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely be looking forward to enjoying the game with his friends and having a good time.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a social person who enjoys spending time with his friends.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jacob Walker went to The Black Swan. Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Clapton Hart. Jacob Walker watched the game at their favourite pub. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, Jacob Walker had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having Jack Taylor at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Jacob Walker, not just watching TV.
          Answer: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jacob Walker went to The Black Swan. Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Clapton Hart. Jacob Walker watched the game at their favourite pub. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, Jacob Walker had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having Jack Taylor at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Jacob Walker, not just watching TV.

          Prompt

        • Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]
          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Observation: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Clapton Hart? It's where I like to watch the games, and it would be more fun with everyone there, especially Jack!

          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a chronic complainer, a black hole of negativity that sucks the joy out of any conversation, leaving you feeling like you've aged a decade.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Black Swan and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a social person who enjoys spending time with his friends.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is spending time with friends at Victoria Park and they are planning to watch a soccer game later.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation with his friends, deciding where to watch a football game.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely suggest a pub to watch the game with his friends.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The Black Swan is the only place to watch the game. The rest are too crowded and noisy.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a social person who enjoys spending time with his friends.

          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation with his friends, deciding where to watch a football game.
          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely suggest a pub to watch the game with his friends.

      • Role playing instructions

          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Black Swan? I know it's a bit more crowded, but Jacob really wants to watch the game there, and it would be great to all be together.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Black Swan? I know it's a bit more crowded, but Jacob really wants to watch the game there, and it would be great to all be together.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could watch the game at The Black Swan tonight?
      Alexander White -- "Mind if I take a stroll around the park? I could use some fresh air.
      Jack Taylor -- "That's a great idea! Watching the game with everyone sounds like a lot more fun than just strolling around.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Black Swan is the only decent place to watch the game. Anywhere else is just a waste of time.
      Alice Lewis -- "A stroll in the park sounds lovely! Fresh air and sunshine will do us all good.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Clapton Hart? It's where I like to watch the games, and it would be more fun with everyone there, especially Jack!
      Jacob Walker -- "The Black Swan is the only place to watch the game. The rest are too crowded and noisy.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Black Swan? I know it's a bit more crowded, but Jacob really wants to watch the game there, and it would be great to all be together.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "The Clapton Hart sounds like a great idea! I've heard it's a good spot to watch games.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "The Clapton Hart sounds like a great idea! I've heard it's a good spot to watch games.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could watch the game at The Black Swan tonight?
      Alexander White -- "Mind if I take a stroll around the park? I could use some fresh air.
      Jack Taylor -- "That's a great idea! Watching the game with everyone sounds like a lot more fun than just strolling around.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Black Swan is the only decent place to watch the game. Anywhere else is just a waste of time.
      Alice Lewis -- "A stroll in the park sounds lovely! Fresh air and sunshine will do us all good.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Clapton Hart? It's where I like to watch the games, and it would be more fun with everyone there, especially Jack!
      Jacob Walker -- "The Black Swan is the only place to watch the game. The rest are too crowded and noisy.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Black Swan? I know it's a bit more crowded, but Jacob really wants to watch the game there, and it would be great to all be together.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "The Clapton Hart sounds like a great idea! I've heard it's a good spot to watch games.

Jacob Walker agrees, stating that The Black Swan is the only place to watch the game because the other pubs are too crowded and noisy. Jack Taylor suggested going to The Black Swan to watch the Luxembourg and Israel game because Jacob Walker really wants to watch it there and it would be great for everyone to be together. Jacob Walker agrees, stating that The Black Swan is the only place to watch the game because the other pubs are too crowded and noisy. Alexander White suggested The Clapton Hart because he likes to watch games there and it would be more fun with everyone, especially Jack.

          Question: Of the options available to Alice Lewis, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alice Lewis to take right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis should go to The Clapton Hart. It is beneficial to both because The Clapton Hart provides a more enjoyable environment for watching the game, accommodating both Alice's preference and Alexander's suggestion.
